results.title: Finale
results.creator_credit: Triangle Productions, Theodora Olembert, Robert Bas and Michael Darlow
results.brief_description: A nostalgic look at the Marlborough Music Hall in North London. It was demolished and we see this being done interspersed with photographs of the famous music hall stars who played there and their special acts.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Triangle Productions, Theodora Olembert, Robert Bas and Michael Darlow

results.title: Final fantasy: the spirits within
results.creator_credit: Chris Lee, Square Co, Columbia Pictures, Jun Aida, Akio Sakai, Hiroonobu Sakaguchi and Motonori Sakakibara
results.brief_description: Based on the Final Fantasy video games, this computer animated feature presents an apocalyptic vision of earth in the not too distant future. The year is 2069; planet earth has now been rendered uninhabitable due to an invasion by a race of phantom like extraterrestrials. What’s left of the human race has now retreated into outer space as they wait and plan a counter-attack against the vicious aliens. Brilliant young scientist Dr. Aki Ross (Ming-Na), is plagued with prophetic dreams about earth’s future. In an attempt to combat the aliens and to find the cure to the deadly ‘alien spirits’ that have infected her body, she joins forces with a prestigious military squad called Deep Eyes. Working with a team of international animators, the filmmakers have managed to create a spectacular if not bleak vision of the future. This is also the first time that animators have attempted to create photo-realistic human characters, meticulously animating every small detail, right down to the movement of each strand of hair on a characters head. Cast voices include Alec Baldwin, James Woods, Donald Sutherland, Ving Rhames and Steve Buscemi.

results.title: fin du jour
results.creator_credit: Filmsonar a Epinay, Regina Film and Julien Duvivier
results.brief_description:
This comedy peeks in at the lives and relationships between elderly thespians living in an actors’ retirement home. The home is almost bankrupt and so the actors must support themselves. The residents include a faded sex symbol, an intellectual actor who kept a great distance between himself and the audience, and a depressed thespian who tries to conceal the fact that he was only an understudy.

Credits: Director, Julien Duvivier ; writers, Charles Spaak, Julien Duvivier ; photography, Christian Matras ; music, Maurice Jaubert ; art direction, Jacques Krauss.
Cast: Louis Jouvet, Michel Simon, Madeleine Ozeray, Victor Francen, Gabrielle Dorziat, Sylvie.

results.title: Films by Harry Smith = Harry Smith: early abstractions
results.brief_description: Harry Smith, filmmaker, painter, anthropologist, linguist, and more, was a unique artist who believed in the interconnectedness of human existence. An anthropology student who became involved in the early incarnation of the counter-culture movement, Smith is credited with developing ingenious methods of animation, collage techniques, and hand-painting directly onto film. No 1: Hand drawn animation of shapes - the history of the geologic period depicted in three minutes. No 2: Geometric shapes, circles, squares, and dirty dots morph to the sounds of the Beatles’ rocking tune “I wanna hold your hand”. No 3: Batiked animation made up of a complex interlocking of squares and oblongs, criss-crossings, leaping on and off the screen. No 4: Black and white abstractions of dots and grillwork, this short work evokes an urban night on the town. No 5: “III Circular tensions” This colour abstraction pays homage to fellow animator Oskar Fischinger. No 6: Optically printed Pythagoreanism in four movements supported on squares, circles, grillwork, and triangles. No 10: An exposition of Buddhism and the Kaballa in the form of a collage.

results.title: Filming the impossible
results.creator_credit: HTV Limited, Leo Dickinson and Aled Vaughan
results.brief_description: Leo Dickinson is an English cameraman who goes to such lengths as parachuting from 8000 feet or suspending himself from ropes above a gorge to get a better camera angle. This film, narrated by Dickinson, shows footage shot by him in the Himalayas and the Sudan. When a comrade falls 150 feet down a mountain and another nearly drowns in the rapids, Dickinson keeps on filming. Two climbers cling like spiders to a twenty-five degree fall, Dickinson is there too. The footage is so beautifully filmed and well edited that it is hard to believe that it was taken under such bad conditions and without time to erect tripods or wait for the right light. Photographed by Leo Dickinson and edited by Terry Elgar.

results.title: Film: the art of the impossible
results.brief_description: Film director Michael Ritchie analyses selected sequences from well known films and demonstrates some of the devices used to make scenes realistic and to create drama. Includes the use of the camera, sound, lighting, script, casting choices and direction of actors, sets, costumes and music.

results.title: Film: a tool for teachers
results.brief_description: This film, designed primarily for teachers in training, has been compiled to demonstrate the possibilities of film as a teaching tool. It consists of excerpts from 18 films, selected because they illustrate the properties peculiar to film for communicating information and ideas. The excerpts are arranged in four groups which illustrate the contribution film can make to four kinds of educational situation: demonstrating practical skills; providing a visual description; organising knowledge and stimulating the imagination.

results.title: Film workshop
results.creator_credit: J B Parsons and Associates and J Parsons
results.brief_description: This film shows the production of two short films by third-year boys at Cornwell Secondary Modern School, East Hampshire. At this school a complete four year syllabus was devised so thet every boy received at least an hour’s screen education each week.

results.title: Film tactics
results.brief_description: A vivid and humorous presentation of how to use sound films to the best effect, and the various results of different kinds of failures on the part of the instructor using a sound film.

results.title: Film strips and splicers
results.brief_description: With transparent, flexible, plastic strips coated with light sensitive gelatine emulsions, film strips were used to capture light and create pictures.
results.description: Before advancements in digital technology made the editing process easier, editors spliced and arranged film strips and frames to tell cohesive stories and represent the director’s vision. Splicers aren’t only used to join lengths of photographic film though, they’re also used to create cuts and transitions, or repair damaged films. They come in a variety of shapes depending on the film stock used, whether that’s Super 8 or 70mm. Tape splicers can be used on most film types and are commonly found in cinemas, where they’re used to join polyester prints. Cement splicers can only be used with acetate, triacetate and nitrate films are they need the film’s emulsion to help bind two lengths with a chemical called film cement.
description_for_label: Before advancements in digital technology made the editing process easier, editors spliced and arranged film strips and frames to tell cohesive stories and represent the director’s vision. Splicers aren’t only used to join lengths of photographic film though, they’re also used to create cuts and transitions, or repair damaged films. Cement splicers can only be used with acetate, triacetate and nitrate films are they need the film’s emulsion to help bind two lengths with a chemical called film cement.
